security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown guidance for Mermaid diagram syntax. The static analyzer flagged 115 patterns as potential security issues, but all are false positives: markdown code fences were misidentified as Ruby backtick execution, hex colour codes were misidentified as weak cryptographic algorithms, and metadata fields were misidentified as system reconnaissance. No executable code, network requests, file system access, or command execution capabilities exist in this skill.

content.user_title: Create beautiful Mermaid diagrams for GitHub
content.value_statement: Mermaid diagrams often break across dark and light modes or use unsupported icons on GitHub. This skill provides proven patterns and templates for creating professional, cross-theme compatible diagrams that render correctly every time.
actual_capabilities: Creates dark/light mode compatible Mermaid diagrams
Shows correct syntax for subgraphs and node shapes
Demonstrates proper styling for subgraphs and links
limitations: Does not execute or render diagrams directly
Cannot generate diagrams from natural language descriptions
Limited to GitHub-compatible Mermaid syntax only

use_cases.title: Process flow documentation

output_examples.input: Create a Mermaid flowchart showing a user login process with validation.
output: A flowchart with user ((circle)) node at the start
Dark fill (#374151) with light stroke (#d1d5db) for theme compatibility
Validation step as a stadium shape (["Validate"])
Subgraphs styled with fill:none for theme adaptability

output_examples.input: Create a Mermaid architecture diagram for a microservices system.
output: Multiple subgraphs representing services (API, Auth, Database)
Professional colour pairs for each component type
Reusable classDef styles at the top for maintainability
Circles for user actors, stadiums for actions, cylinders for storage

output_examples.input: Create a Mermaid diagram showing a data pipeline process.
output: Linear flowchart with source, processing, and destination stages
Consistent styling across all pipeline nodes
Success paths shown in green, branching logic in orange
Proper subgraph encapsulation for each pipeline stage

best_practices: Always use dark fills with light strokes and white text for cross-theme compatibility
Define all classDef styles at the top of your diagram for maintainability
Set subgraph fills to none so they adapt to any background colour
anti_patterns: Using light fills with dark text makes text invisible in dark mode
Font Awesome icons (fa:fa-*) render as literal text on GitHub
Unquoted subgraph labels with spaces cause parse errors

faq.question: What Mermaid diagram types are supported?
faq.answer: GitHub supports flowcharts, sequence diagrams, class diagrams, state diagrams, entity-relationship diagrams, user journey, and Gantt charts.

faq.question: Do diagrams work in private repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, Mermaid diagrams render correctly in both public and private GitHub repositories using the same syntax.

faq.question: How do I preview diagrams before committing?
faq.answer: Use mermaid.live to preview your diagrams. Copy the code, render it there, then paste into your markdown.

faq.question: Can I use custom colours?
faq.answer: Yes, any hex colour works. Just follow the dark fill + light stroke + white text pattern for theme compatibility.

faq.question: Do diagram animations work on GitHub?
faq.answer: No, GitHub renders static diagrams. Animations work only in local Mermaid viewers like mermaid.live.

faq.question: What is the difference between classDef and style?
faq.answer: classDef creates reusable named styles applied with ::: syntax. style applies inline to specific nodes. Use classDef for consistency.
